The chronic course and severe pruritus lead to excoriation and secondary changes. Unlike **linear IgA bullous dermatosis** (chronic bullous disease of childhood), which shows **annular "cluster of jewels"** configuration and often involves perioral and genital areas, dermatitis herpetiformis demonstrates symmetric extensor involvement. **Atopic eczema** typically affects **flexural surfaces** rather than extensors and shows lichenification more than vesiculation. The distribution, chronicity, and intense pruritus confirm dermatitis herpetiformis.

question: A 56 year male patient presented with lesion over the sole of the right foot of 08 months duration associated with pain during walking & loss of weight. Two months back he also noticed a painful swelling over the rightinguinal area which is progressively increasing in size. On P/E there is a hard 10x8 cm matted, hard, fixed & tender swelling over the right inguinal region with an irregularly shaped plaque like dark lesion over the right sole of the foot. A skin biopsy was taken from the lesion over the foot. What would be the biopsy result of this patient?
explanation: This patient has a dark, irregular plaque on the plantar foot with painful ambulation, constitutional symptoms (weight loss), and **matted, fixed inguinal lymphadenopathy**, which is most consistent with **acral lentiginous melanoma**. **Acral lentiginous melanoma** arises from melanocytes on palms, soles, or subungual regions—the most common melanoma subtype in darkly pigmented populations and the only melanoma type not associated with UV exposure. The **plantar location**, irregular pigmentation, and aggressive behavior with early **lymphatic spread** distinguish this variant. Metastasis to **regional lymph nodes** (inguinal basin for lower extremity primaries) manifests as matted, fixed, hard nodal masses reflecting extracapsular tumor extension. The eight-month primary lesion duration followed by two-month lymphadenopathy progression indicates vertical growth phase transition to metastatic disease. Unlike **squamous cell carcinoma**, which presents as scaly, hyperkeratotic plaques rather than darkly pigmented lesions, acral melanoma demonstrates characteristic pigmentation. **Basal cell carcinoma** almost never occurs on palms/soles and lacks melanin pigmentation. The plantar location, dark pigmentation, and regional metastases confirm acral melanoma.

question: A 46 years old female, fair skinned patient, came with a 2 cm blackish plaque lesion which has color variation, asymmetry and ragged boarder. What is the most likely diagnosis of her condition?
explanation: This patient has a pigmented lesion with **asymmetry**, **color variation** (variegation), and **irregular borders** in a fair-skinned individual, which is most consistent with **cutaneous melanoma**. **Melanoma** arises from malignant transformation of melanocytes following cumulative DNA damage from **UV radiation exposure**, particularly in individuals with fair skin (Fitzpatrick types I-II) who lack protective melanin. The **ABCDE criteria**—Asymmetry, Border irregularity, Color variation, Diameter >6mm, Evolution—guide clinical recognition. **Color variegation** (black, brown, red, blue, white areas) reflects heterogeneous melanin production and tumor regression. **Asymmetry** indicates disorganized growth from loss of cell cycle control; **irregular borders** result from radial growth phase extension. Fair skin confers 10-20 times higher melanoma risk compared to darker skin types. Unlike **basal cell carcinoma**, which appears pearly translucent with telangiectasia rather than darkly pigmented, melanoma demonstrates pronounced pigment heterogeneity. **Squamous cell carcinoma** presents as scaly, flesh-colored nodules without dark pigmentation. The combination of ABCDE features in a fair-skinned patient confirms melanoma diagnosis requiring urgent excisional biopsy.

question: A 40 year old patient whom you have treated for possible vulvar lichen sclerosis with topical steroid comes 3 months after finishing her therapy. She still complains vulvar pruritus and on examination there is thinning of skin with hypopigmentation and excoriation marks. What investigation would you do next?
explanation: This patient has persistent vulvar pruritus despite completed **lichen sclerosus** treatment, with thinning skin, hypopigmentation, and excoriation marks, indicating need for **vulvar biopsy** to evaluate treatment failure and exclude malignant transformation. **Lichen sclerosus** causes chronic lymphocytic inflammation of the **vulvar dermis** resulting in dermal sclerosis, epidermal atrophy, and loss of melanocytes—manifesting as white, atrophic plaques. While topical **high-potency corticosteroids** (clobetasol) achieve remission in most patients, persistent symptoms after adequate therapy raise concern for **inadequate treatment response** or **progression to vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN)** or **squamous cell carcinoma**. **Lichen sclerosus** confers 4-5% lifetime risk of vulvar malignancy. Persistent pruritus, new nodularity, ulceration, or treatment-refractory lesions mandate biopsy to exclude dysplasia or invasive cancer. Unlike potassium hydroxide preparation (for fungal evaluation), biopsy provides definitive histologic diagnosis distinguishing persistent inflammatory disease from neoplastic transformation. **Colposcopy** and aceto-white staining evaluate cervical/vaginal epithelium but lack the diagnostic specificity needed for vulvar pathology. The treatment failure and malignancy risk necessitate tissue diagnosis.

question: A 7 years old female patient present with intensely itchy bullous lesion over the extensor aspect of extremities of 2 months. On physical exam there are excoriated plaques and vesicles with scratch marks. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient has intensely pruritic vesicles and bullae over **extensor surfaces** of extremities in a 7-year-old child with chronic two-month duration and excoriations from scratching, which is most consistent with **dermatitis herpetiformis**. **Dermatitis herpetiformis** results from **IgA antibodies** against epidermal transglutaminase depositing at the **dermal-epidermal junction**, triggering neutrophil recruitment and complement activation that causes subepidermal blister formation. Nearly all patients have associated **celiac disease** (gluten-sensitive enteropathy), though intestinal symptoms may be subclinical. The pathognomonic **extensor surface distribution** (elbows, knees, buttocks, scalp) with intensely pruritic grouped vesicles distinguishes this from other bullous disorders. The chronic course and severe pruritus lead to excoriation and secondary changes. Unlike **linear IgA bullous dermatosis** (chronic bullous disease of childhood), which shows **annular "cluster of jewels"** configuration and often involves perioral and genital areas, dermatitis herpetiformis demonstrates symmetric extensor involvement. **Atopic eczema** typically affects **flexural surfaces** rather than extensors and shows lichenification more than vesiculation. The distribution, chronicity, and intense pruritus confirm dermatitis herpetiformis.

question: A 38 years old female patient came with redness and burning sensation of the central facial area upon sun exposure. She used to apply topical steroid for melasma without seeing a physician. Which of the following is the least likely to be seen in this patient?
explanation: This patient has central facial redness and burning triggered by sun exposure following chronic unsupervised **topical corticosteroid** use for melasma, consistent with **steroid rosacea** (perioral dermatitis). **Lichenification** is least likely in this condition. Chronic topical corticosteroid application to facial skin causes **dermal atrophy** through inhibition of collagen synthesis and fibroblast activity, **telangiectasia** from vascular wall weakening and dilation, and **hypertrichosis** from altered hair follicle hormone sensitivity. The compromised skin barrier and vascular changes create **steroid-induced rosacea-like dermatitis**, characterized by persistent erythema, burning, and rebound inflammation upon steroid discontinuation. Sun exposure exacerbates symptoms through additional barrier disruption. **Lichenification** (thickened, leathery skin with accentuated markings) develops from chronic **rubbing or scratching** in conditions like **atopic dermatitis** or chronic eczema, representing epidermal hyperplasia as a protective response to repeated mechanical trauma. Steroid-induced facial changes involve dermal thinning and vascular proliferation rather than epidermal thickening. Unlike lichenified dermatoses affecting flexural areas, steroid rosacea demonstrates atrophy and telangiectasia without lichenification.

question: A 55 year old carpenter sustained prick injury to his right thumb a week back. He started to have pain and swelling three days after the injury. The worsening of pain and swelling is the reason he presented to your OPD. The clinical picture of the thumb is show below. What is the most likely diagnosis of the patient?
explanation: This patient has progressive pain and swelling of the thumb following puncture injury with onset three days post-trauma in a carpenter (high contamination risk), which is most consistent with **felon**. A **felon** is a closed-space infection of the **pulp** (volar fat pad) of the distal phalanx, typically caused by **Staphylococcus aureus** or **Streptococcus** entering through penetrating trauma. The pulp space contains multiple fibrous **vertical septa** connecting volar skin to periosteum, creating small compartments. Bacterial inoculation causes purulent collection that cannot decompress, leading to rapidly escalating pressure within these rigid compartments. This pressure compromises digital artery perfusion, risks **septic flexor tenosynovitis** if infection spreads proximally, and can cause **osteomyelitis** of the distal phalanx. The three-day post-injury onset and occupational exposure (carpenter with potential wood splinter contamination) fit typical presentation. Unlike **paronychia**, which affects the **lateral or proximal nail fold** rather than pulp space, felon causes diffuse pulp swelling. **Herpetic whitlow** presents with grouped vesicles and usually affects healthcare workers. **Flexor tenosynovitis** shows **Kanavel's four signs** including pain with passive extension along the entire flexor sheath.

question: A 36 years old male came with pruritic papules and pustules over the beard area of two days duration after shaving. After investigation he was told that it is not an infectious origin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient has acute-onset pruritic papules and pustules in the beard area following shaving, with non-infectious etiology confirmed by investigation, which is most consistent with **pseudofolliculitis barbae**. **Pseudofolliculitis barbae** is a sterile inflammatory condition resulting from **curved hair shafts** (particularly in individuals of African descent with tightly coiled hair) re-entering the skin after close shaving, triggering a **foreign body inflammatory response**. As shaved hair grows, the sharp tip penetrates adjacent epidermis or dermis (extrafollicular or transfollicular penetration), causing keratinocyte damage and recruitment of inflammatory cells (lymphocytes, neutrophils). This produces erythematous papules, pustules, and hyperpigmented scarring. The two-day post-shaving onset and non-infectious nature distinguish this from bacterial folliculitis. Unlike **sycosis barbae** (bacterial folliculitis caused by **Staphylococcus aureus**), which would show positive bacterial cultures and respond to antibiotics, pseudofolliculitis barbae has negative cultures and is mechanically induced. **Folliculitis keloidalis** and **acne keloidalis nuchae** affect the posterior neck/occipital scalp with chronic papules progressing to keloid-like scarring rather than acute beard area involvement.

question: A 25 years old patient presented with exfoliating lesion over trauma prone areas of the body since 5 years. Morphologically the lesions are thickened, erythematous plaque with silvery white scaling; removal of the scale reveals a pin point bleeding underneath. Which system is most likely to be involved in the disease process?
explanation: This patient has chronic erythematous plaques with silvery scales on trauma-prone areas, **Auspitz sign** (pinpoint bleeding with scale removal), suggesting **psoriasis**, which most commonly involves the **cardiovascular** system. **Psoriasis** is a chronic inflammatory disorder driven by **T-cell mediated** immune dysregulation causing keratinocyte hyperproliferation. Elevated **proinflammatory cytokines** (TNF-α, IL-17, IL-23) not only accelerate epidermal turnover (creating scale) but also promote **systemic endothelial dysfunction**, **atherosclerosis**, and **metabolic syndrome**. Psoriasis patients have 1.5-2 times increased risk of **myocardial infarction**, **stroke**, and cardiovascular mortality independent of traditional risk factors. The chronic inflammatory state accelerates coronary plaque formation through multiple mechanisms: oxidative stress, dyslipidemia, insulin resistance, and direct vascular inflammation. The **Koebner phenomenon** (lesions at trauma sites) and **Auspitz sign** (pinpoint bleeding from dilated dermal capillaries when scale removed) confirm psoriasis. Unlike conditions primarily affecting renal, gastrointestinal, or nervous systems, psoriasis demonstrates strongest association with cardiovascular morbidity requiring aggressive cardiovascular risk modification alongside skin-directed therapy.

question: A 22 year old patient presented with red macules and papules on the trunk and extremities symmetrically of 5 days duration. She was taking non-specific oral medication for an infection. What is the drug responsible for such reaction?
explanation: This patient has symmetric maculopapular drug eruption on the trunk and extremities following antibiotic use, which is most consistent with **co-trimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole)**. **Maculopapular drug eruptions** result from **T-cell mediated hypersensitivity** (Type IV) where drug metabolites or the drug itself acts as a hapten, binding to skin proteins and triggering delayed immune activation. **Sulfonamides** (including co-trimoxazole) are among the most common causes of maculopapular eruptions, occurring in 3-5% of users, with higher risk in HIV-positive patients (30-60%). The reaction typically begins **7-14 days** after drug initiation (or 1-3 days with re-exposure) as T-cell priming requires time for antigen presentation and clonal expansion. The symmetric truncal and extremity distribution reflects hematogenous drug dissemination. **Co-trimoxazole** causes significantly more cutaneous reactions than other common antibiotics due to the **sulfonamide** component's metabolism producing reactive metabolites that conjugate with tissue proteins. Unlike other listed antibiotics with lower eruption rates (azithromycin <1%, ciprofloxacin <1%, tetracycline <1%), sulfonamides demonstrate the highest propensity for maculopapular eruptions. The five-day onset timing and symmetric distribution confirm drug hypersensitivity.

question: A 59 year old male patient presented with a skin lesion of 1 year duration. He also has weight loss and anorexia. On examination, he has a darkly pigmented plaque with central fungating ulcer on the left plantar area. He also has bilateral palpable inguinal lymph nodes. Skin biopsy showed oval to round cells that shows atypia and have darkly pigmented cytoplasm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient has a darkly pigmented plaque with ulceration on the plantar surface, constitutional symptoms (weight loss, anorexia), bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy, and histology showing atypical cells with pigmented cytoplasm, which is most consistent with **acral lentiginous melanoma**. **Acral lentiginous melanoma** arises from melanocytes on **palms, soles, or subungual regions**—the most common melanoma subtype in darkly pigmented populations and the only melanoma not associated with UV exposure. Histologically, atypical melanocytes show **epithelioid or spindle morphology** with abundant **melanin-laden cytoplasm** and nuclear atypia. The aggressive behavior includes early **vertical growth phase** with deep dermal invasion and frequent **lymphatic metastasis**. **Bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy** indicates regional nodal involvement, confirmed by the constitutional symptoms suggesting advanced disease. The one-year duration with progressive ulceration reflects transition from radial to vertical growth. Unlike **pigmented basal cell carcinoma**, which shows basaloid keratinocytes (not melanocytes) and rarely metastasizes, acral melanoma demonstrates melanocytic atypia with aggressive metastatic potential. **Squamous cell carcinoma** lacks melanin pigmentation. The plantar location, pigmented cytology, and nodal spread confirm acral lentiginous melanoma.

question: A 34 year old a known asthmatic patient on regular followup presented with a newly erupting skin lesions over the arms and the legs of two weeks duration. On evaluation at the dermatology clinic, erythematous and edematous plaquestopped with vesicles and erosions was observed over antecubital and popliteal fossae bilaterally. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient has asthma, new-onset pruritic vesicular eruption involving **flexural surfaces** (antecubital and popliteal fossae) bilaterally, which is most consistent with **atopic dermatitis**. **Atopic dermatitis** is a chronic inflammatory skin disorder characterized by defective **epidermal barrier function** (filaggrin mutations reduce natural moisturizing factors) and **Th2-mediated immune dysregulation** producing elevated IgE and eosinophils. The disorder frequently coexists with other **atopic conditions** (asthma, allergic rhinitis)—the "atopic march." In adults and older children, lesions preferentially affect **flexural areas** (antecubital fossae, popliteal fossae, neck, wrists) where skin-on-skin contact increases moisture and friction. Acute flares show erythema, edema, vesicles, and weeping; chronic lesions develop lichenification. The two-week acute presentation in a known asthmatic represents classic atopic dermatitis exacerbation. Unlike **allergic contact dermatitis**, which requires exposure to specific allergen and shows distribution matching contact pattern rather than symmetric flexural involvement, atopic dermatitis demonstrates characteristic flexural distribution. **Stevens-Johnson syndrome** causes mucosal involvement with targetoid lesions and systemic toxicity, not isolated flexural eczematous changes. The asthma history and flexural distribution confirm atopic dermatitis.

question: A 50 year old male patient has a pigmented skin lesion on the scalp that has recently changed in color and has become itchy and started to bleed. There are few small black spots irregularly scattered around the lesion.What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient has a pigmented scalp lesion with recent changes (color variation, pruritus, bleeding) and **satellite lesions** (black spots scattered around primary lesion), which is most consistent with **malignant melanoma**. **Melanoma** arises from malignant transformation of melanocytes, demonstrating uncontrolled proliferation with loss of normal growth regulation. Recent **changes** in a pigmented lesion—particularly color evolution, new symptoms (itching, bleeding), or diameter increase—indicate transition from radial to **vertical growth phase**, signaling increased invasion potential and metastatic risk. **Satellite lesions** (pigmented macules within 2 cm of primary tumor) represent **local dermal or lymphatic metastases**, indicating advanced local disease (Stage IIIB or higher). The scalp location increases mortality risk due to frequent delayed diagnosis (hidden by hair) and rich lymphatic drainage. Bleeding indicates ulceration, an independent poor prognostic factor. Unlike **Bowen's disease** (squamous cell carcinoma in situ), which presents as well-demarcated erythematous scaly plaques without pigmentation, melanoma shows characteristic dark pigmentation and satellite spread. **Basal cell carcinoma** appears pearly and translucent rather than darkly pigmented. The recent changes, bleeding, and satellite lesions confirm invasive melanoma.

question: A 54 year old female patient has sustained scald burnin her left arm two years ago. She treated the wound by homemade remedies. The wound had formed unstable scar and frequently ulcerates. In the past three months therecurrent ulcer persisted. Which skin cancer is the patient most likely to develop?
explanation: This patient has chronic, non-healing ulcer in a burn scar site with persistent ulceration for three months, which is most consistent with **squamous cell carcinoma** arising in a **Marjolin ulcer**. **Marjolin ulcer** is **squamous cell carcinoma** developing in chronically inflamed tissue, classically in burn scars but also in chronic wounds, pressure ulcers, or osteomyelitis sites. The malignant transformation occurs after prolonged **chronic inflammation** (typically 10-40 years, though can occur earlier) through repeated cycles of tissue injury, repair, and proliferation that accumulate DNA damage in keratinocytes. **Chronic wounds** show persistent inflammatory cytokine release, reactive oxygen species production, and impaired apoptosis—creating an environment favoring malignant transformation. SCCs arising in Marjolin ulcers demonstrate **aggressive behavior** with higher rates of local recurrence (20-30%) and metastasis (20-30%) compared to UV-induced SCCs due to delayed diagnosis and altered tumor biology in chronically inflamed tissue. Unlike **basal cell carcinoma**, which rarely arises in scars and is primarily UV-induced, SCC shows strong association with chronic wounds. **Melanoma** requires melanocyte transformation and doesn't typically arise in burn scars. The two-year burn history with unstable scar and three-month persistent ulceration indicate high-risk Marjolin ulcer.

question: A 40-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of a painless lump in her left breast that she noticed 2 months ago. She has no family history of breast cancer. On physical examination, the lump is firm, mobile, and well-circumscribed. It measures about 3 cm in diameter and is located in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There is no nipple discharge, skin changes, or axillary lymphadenopathy. A mammogram shows a round mass with smooth margins and no calcifications. A biopsy of the mass is most likely to show which of the following histological features?
explanation: This patient has a painless, mobile, well-circumscribed breast mass with smooth margins on mammography and no concerning features (lymphadenopathy, skin changes, calcifications), which is most consistent with **fibroadenoma**. **Fibroadenoma** is a benign **stromal and epithelial** proliferation most common in women age 20-40, representing the most frequent benign breast mass. The tumor arises from lobular stroma showing both fibroblastic proliferation and glandular epithelial hyperplasia. The characteristic **mobility** ("breast mouse") reflects lack of invasion into surrounding tissue; **well-defined borders** result from encapsulation; **firm texture** comes from dense fibrous stroma. Mammography shows **round or oval mass** with **smooth, sharply defined margins** and homogeneous density without calcifications. Size typically ranges 1-3 cm. Histology demonstrates **biphasic pattern** with benign epithelial elements (glands, ducts) surrounded by cellular stromal proliferation. Unlike malignancies showing **irregular margins**, **fixed position**, or **microcalcifications**, fibroadenoma demonstrates benign imaging characteristics. **Invasive carcinomas** would show spiculated borders, lymphadenopathy, or skin tethering. The patient's age, mobile mass, and smooth margins on imaging confirm fibroadenoma diagnosis.

question: A 16-year-old girl presents with a skin lesion on her face that she noticed a month ago. She says that it is not painful or itchy, but it is cosmetically bothersome. She also mentions that her father and grandfather have similar lesions. On physical examination, the lesion is a well-defined, hyperpigmented patch with irregular borders and atrophic changes. A skin biopsy shows a marked decrease in melanocytes and keratinocytes, and an increase in fibroblasts and collagen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient has a hyperpigmented facial patch with atrophy, positive family history (father, grandfather), and histology showing decreased melanocytes/keratinocytes with increased fibrosis, which is most consistent with **xeroderma pigmentosum**. **Xeroderma pigmentosum** is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in **nucleotide excision repair (NER)** genes, impairing removal of UV-induced DNA damage (thymine dimers). Early childhood onset of **photosensitivity** with severe sunburn, followed by progressive **pigmentary changes** (freckling, hyperpigmentation, hypopigmentation), **skin atrophy**, and **premature aging** characterize this condition. The histologic findings—decreased melanocytes and keratinocytes with dermal fibrosis—reflect chronic UV damage and premature photoaging. Patients develop **skin cancers** (basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, melanoma) by age 10-20 with 1000-fold increased risk. The familial pattern, atrophic hyperpigmented lesion, and characteristic histology indicate xeroderma pigmentosum. Unlike **vitiligo**, which shows complete depigmentation from melanocyte destruction without atrophy, xeroderma pigmentosum demonstrates mixed pigmentation with atrophic changes. **Melasma** shows epidermal hyperpigmentation without atrophy or decreased melanocyte count. The family history and histologic features confirm xeroderma pigmentosum.

question: A 17-year-old boy presents with multiple skin lesions on his face, chest, and back that he has had for the past year. He is embarrassed by his appearance and has low self-esteem. He has tried various over-the-counter products, but none of them have worked. On physical examination, the lesions are open and closed comedones, papules, pustules, and nodules. Some of the lesions are inflamed and have pus. A skin culture is negative for bacteria. What is the most typical feature of this condition?
explanation: This patient has multiple facial and truncal lesions including **comedones** (open and closed), papules, pustules, and nodules with negative bacterial culture, which is most consistent with **acne vulgaris**, and **comedones** are the most typical feature. **Acne vulgaris** results from four pathophysiologic factors: (1) **follicular hyperkeratinization** creating keratin plugs that obstruct pilosebaceous units, (2) increased **sebum production** from androgenic stimulation, (3) colonization by **Propionibacterium acnes**, and (4) inflammatory cascade activation. **Comedones**—the hallmark lesion—form when keratin and sebum accumulate behind the obstructed follicular opening. **Closed comedones** (whiteheads) have microscopic openings; **open comedones** (blackheads) oxidize, producing dark color. Inflammatory lesions (papules, pustules, nodules) develop when P. acnes triggers innate immune responses, but the organism is commensal rather than pathogenic (explaining negative culture). Comedones represent the primary and earliest lesion defining acne. Unlike cysts (severe nodulocystic acne variant) or scars (sequelae), comedones are universally present and pathognomonic for acne vulgaris. Papules represent secondary inflammation. The negative culture, comedonal predominance, and distribution confirm acne vulgaris with comedones as the defining feature.

question: A 35-year-old woman is admitted to the burn unit with skin lesions involving 80% of her body surface area. She says that she developed a rash after taking ibuprofen for a headache, and then the rash progressed to blisters and erosions. She also has fever, malaise, and conjunctivitis. On physical examination, the skin lesions are widespread, red, and tender, and they easily detach with gentle pressure, leaving raw and bleeding areas. A skin biopsy shows full-thickness epidermal necrosis and subepidermal detachment. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient has drug-induced extensive skin detachment (80% BSA), fever, mucositis (conjunctivitis), positive Nikolsky sign, and histology showing **full-thickness epidermal necrosis**, which is most consistent with **toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)**. **TEN** represents a severe **cytotoxic T-cell and NK cell-mediated** reaction causing widespread keratinocyte apoptosis through **Fas-FasL** and **granulysin** pathways. Drug-specific cytotoxic lymphocytes recognize drug-peptide complexes on keratinocytes, triggering massive apoptosis and full-thickness epidermal necrosis. **NSAIDs** (including ibuprofen), anticonvulsants, allopurinol, and sulfonamides are common triggers. TEN is defined by **>30% BSA involvement** with sheet-like epidermal detachment (10-30% BSA = Stevens-Johnson syndrome/TEN overlap; 30%), drug trigger, and full-thickness necrosis distinguish TEN from SJS.

question: An RVI patient presented with itchy skin lesions circular lesions with central clearing and peripheral papular and pustular lesions. He has a history of travel to a rural area in South America, where he was exposed to sand flies. On examination, he has lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient has circular lesions with central clearing, exposure to **sandflies** in South America, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly, which is most consistent with **cutaneous leishmaniasis** with systemic involvement (suggesting visceral leishmaniasis). **Leishmaniasis** is caused by **Leishmania** protozoa transmitted by female **Phlebotomus** (Old World) or **Lutzomyia** (New World) sandfly bites. **Cutaneous leishmaniasis** typically presents as papules evolving into nodules with central ulceration and raised borders ("volcano sign") at bite sites. The described circular lesions with peripheral activity and central clearing likely represent healing cutaneous lesions. However, lymphadenopathy and **hepatosplenomegaly** indicate **visceral leishmaniasis** (kala-azar), where parasites disseminate to reticuloendothelial organs via macrophage infection. Visceral disease manifests with fever, massive splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, pancytopenia, and hypergammaglobulinemia. South American travel, sandfly exposure, and systemic findings strongly suggest leishmaniasis. Unlike **tinea corporis** (dermatophyte infection) showing annular scaling without systemic features, leishmaniasis demonstrates protozoan infection with potential visceral spread. **Scabies** causes intense pruritus without organomegaly. The travel history, vector exposure, and systemic involvement confirm leishmaniasis.

question: A 35-year-old man presents to the dermatologist with a complaint of a scaly rash on his elbows, knees, and scalp. He says that he has been experiencing itching, flaking, and bleeding of the affected areas for the past year. He also notices that his fingernails have become thickened and pitted. He has no history of allergies, asthma, or immunodeficiency. He is not taking any medications. His family history is significant for his father having psoriatic arthritis. His vital signs are: temperature 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse 80 beats/min, respirations 16 breaths/min, blood pressure 120/80 mm Hg. On physical examination, he has well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales on his extensor surfaces and scalp. He also has nail dystrophy and onycholysis. His joint examination is normal, with no swelling, tenderness, or deformity. His laboratory tests are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
explanation: This patient has well-demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery scales on extensor surfaces, **nail pitting** and **onycholysis**, positive family history of psoriatic arthritis, which is most consistent with **psoriasis**. **Psoriasis** is a chronic inflammatory disorder driven by **T-cell mediated** immune dysregulation causing accelerated keratinocyte turnover (from normal 28 days to 3-5 days). Proinflammatory cytokines triggering epidermal hyperproliferation, producing characteristic **silvery scales** from accumulated parakeratotic stratum corneum. **Extensor surface predilection** (elbows, knees, scalp) and **nail involvement** (pitting from focal inflammatory disruption of nail matrix, onycholysis from subungual hyperkeratosis) are highly characteristic. **Auspitz sign** (pinpoint bleeding with scale removal) occurs from dilated dermal papillary capillaries. Family history of **psoriatic arthritis** increases genetic susceptibility (HLA-Cw6 association). Unlike **atopic dermatitis** affecting **flexural surfaces** with lichenification, psoriasis demonstrates extensor involvement with distinct silvery scale. **Lichen planus** shows violaceous polygonal papules on flexor surfaces with Wickham striae. The extensor distribution, nail changes, and family history confirm psoriasis.

question: A 45-year-old woman presents to the dermatologist with a complaint of a mole on her back. She says that she noticed the mole about six months ago, and that it has been changing in size, shape, and color. She has no history of sunburns, tanning, or immunosuppression. She is not taking any medications. Her family history is negative for skin cancer. Her vital signs are: temperature 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse 70 beats/min, respirations 14 breaths/min, blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg. On physical examination, she has a 1.5 cm, asymmetric, irregular, multicolored lesion with a raised border on her upper back. There is no ulceration, bleeding, or lymphadenopathy. Her laboratory tests are normal. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
options: Excise the lesion with a 2 mm margin
Excise the lesion with a 5 mm margin
explanation: This patient has a pigmented lesion with asymmetry, irregular borders, color variation, and recent changes (meeting multiple ABCDE criteria for melanoma), requiring **excision with 5 mm margin** for complete histologic assessment. Lesions suspicious for **melanoma** require complete excisional biopsy with narrow margins (typically 1-3 mm clinical margin, often described as 2-5 mm) to allow full-thickness histologic evaluation including **Breslow depth** measurement—the most critical prognostic factor determining staging and management. **Excisional biopsy** provides intact specimen architecture for accurate depth measurement, assessment of ulceration, mitotic rate, and margin status. **Narrow margins** (2-5 mm) at initial biopsy prevent unnecessary wide excision if the lesion proves benign while allowing adequate tissue for diagnosis. Definitive wide local excision with margins based on Breslow depth (0.5-2 cm) follows diagnosis confirmation. **Punch biopsy** risks sampling error in heterogeneous melanomas and cannot reliably assess depth. **Shave biopsy** or cryotherapy would be inappropriate for suspected melanoma. The 5 mm margin option provides complete excision for diagnostic purposes without excessive tissue removal pending histology.

question: A 60-year-oldman visits the dermatology clinic with a complaint of a mole on his back that has changed in appearance over the past few months. He has a history of chronic sun exposure and multiple sunburns. He has no other medical problems and takes no medications. On examination, he has a 1.5-cm pigmented lesion on his upper back, with irregular borders, asymmetry, color variation, and elevation. A biopsy of the lesion reveals malignant melanoma. Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor for this patient?
explanation: This patient has confirmed melanoma with multiple ABCDE criteria features, and **Breslow thickness** represents the most important prognostic factor for determining survival and guiding surgical management. **Breslow thickness** measures tumor depth in millimeters from the **granular layer** of epidermis (or ulcer base if ulcerated) to the deepest point of invasion. This measurement directly correlates with metastatic potential and survival: melanomas 95% 10-year survival, 1-2 mm have ~90%, 2-4 mm have ~75%, and >4 mm have 2 mm) and need for **sentinel lymph node biopsy** (recommended for tumors ≥0.8 mm or with high-risk features). The AJCC staging system prioritizes Breslow thickness as the primary T-stage determinant. **Clark level** (anatomic depth: epidermis, papillary dermis, reticular dermis, subcutis) was historically used but has been largely replaced by Breslow measurement due to superior prognostic accuracy and reproducibility. **Mitotic rate** and **age** influence prognosis but remain secondary to Breslow thickness in determining management and survival prediction.

question: A 20 year old male patient sustained blunt abdominal trauma with guarding and unstable vital signs, other examination was unremarkable. He was diagnosed to have hemorrhagic shock with intra-peritoneal hemorrhage. At the ER, double IV line was secured and resuscitated with four bags of N/S, then the BP increased to 80/50 mmHg. What is the next best management for the above case?
options: Take the patient to OR for exploration
Continue on resuscitation until vital sign is stabilized
explanation: Blunt abdominal trauma with **guarding**, **persistent hypotension (80/50 mmHg)** after 4L crystalloid resuscitation, and **unstable vital signs** indicates **hemorrhagic shock from intra-peritoneal hemorrhage**, which results from **disruption of solid organ parenchyma or mesenteric vessels** leading to **ongoing blood loss** exceeding compensatory mechanisms. The management decision hinges on **transient response to resuscitation**, defined as temporary BP improvement followed by deterioration, signaling **active uncontrolled hemorrhage** requiring immediate surgical control. Continued conservative management excluded because patient demonstrates **hemodynamic instability despite aggressive fluid resuscitation** and would not achieve **sustained stabilization** without **definitive hemorrhage control** through direct vessel ligation or organ repair. Because **active intra-peritoneal hemorrhage with transient resuscitation response** mandates immediate surgical intervention, delaying risks **exsanguination through progressive hypovolemia** and **irreversible coagulopathy from consumption**, therefore **emergency laparotomy** is required. Initiated **before achieving complete hemodynamic normalization** because **uncontrolled surgical bleeding cannot be managed non-operatively**, and waiting for full stabilization causes **lethal hemorrhage** in patients with **ongoing vascular disruption**. **Inotropes** are contraindicated because **inadequate preload from hypovolemia** precludes effective cardiac contractility augmentation, risking **tissue hypoperfusion** without addressing the **source control** imperative.

question: A 20 year old male patient sustained bullet injury to his chest of one hour duration. On examination airway was intact but he was in respiratory distress with use of accessory muscles. He had sucking wound with a decreased air entry of the left side. What is the first option of management?
explanation: Penetrating chest trauma with **sucking chest wound**, **respiratory distress with accessory muscle use**, **decreased air entry on left side**, and **preserved airway patency** indicates **open pneumothorax**, which results from **chest wall defect >2/3 tracheal diameter** allowing **bidirectional air flow** through the wound during respiration, leading to **impaired negative intrapleural pressure** and **inadequate lung expansion**. The management decision hinges on **immediate conversion to closed system**, as open communication between atmosphere and pleural space prevents effective ventilation. Tension pneumothorax excluded because patient lacks **hemodynamic instability, tracheal deviation, or JVD** and would not demonstrate **stable BP** with **mediastinal shift** from progressive air accumulation under pressure. Because **open pneumothorax with ongoing air entrainment** creates immediate ventilatory compromise, delaying risks **hypoxemic respiratory failure** through **persistent lung collapse**, therefore **three-sided occlusive dressing** is required. Applied **before chest tube insertion** because **immediate wound occlusion** converts open to **closed pneumothorax**, restoring **negative intrapleural pressure** for ventilation, whereas proceeding directly to tube thoracostomy leaves **atmospheric communication open** during preparation, worsening **hypoxemia** in patients with **large chest wall defects**. **Needle decompression** is contraindicated because **open wound** already provides atmospheric communication, making **additional pleural access unnecessary** and risking **iatrogenic lung injury** without addressing the **primary pathology**.

question: A 25 year old female patient involved in road traffic accident and presented to the emergency department with an injury to her left leg with a huge de gloved wound. What is the best solution to irrigate this wound?
explanation: Road traffic accident with **degloving injury to left leg** and **large contaminated wound** indicates **traumatic soft tissue avulsion**, which results from **tangential shearing forces** separating **skin and subcutaneous tissue from underlying fascia**, leading to **devascularized tissue flaps** and **bacterial contamination** from environmental exposure. The management decision hinges on **isotonic crystalloid irrigation** that mechanically removes debris without causing **cellular toxicity** or **tissue edema**. Alternative antiseptic solutions excluded because **chemical cytotoxicity** would impair **wound healing** through **fibroblast damage** and would not provide **superior infection prevention** compared to **high-volume mechanical lavage** in grossly contaminated injuries. Because **contaminated degloving wounds** require debris removal while preserving viable tissue, delaying risks **deep space infection** through **bacterial proliferation** in devitalized planes, therefore **normal saline irrigation** is required. Preferred **before antiseptic application** because **isotonic crystalloid** maintains **cellular integrity** through **osmotic equilibrium**, whereas **hypotonic or cytotoxic agents** cause **osmotic cell lysis** and **impaired granulation**, violating **wound healing principles** in injuries requiring **tissue preservation** for potential **flap salvage** or **grafting**.

question: A 25 year old patient came to the emergency department after road traffic accident with compound femoral fracture with active bleeding. On examination his blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg, pulse rate of 130/min, hemoglobin of 5gm/dl, blood group not determined. Which type of blood can be given to the patient as an emergency?
explanation: Road traffic accident with **compound femoral fracture**, **active bleeding**, **hypotension (80/50 mmHg)**, **tachycardia (130 bpm)**, **severe anemia (Hgb 5 g/dL)**, and **unknown blood type** indicates **class III hemorrhagic shock**, which results from **>30% blood volume loss** from **major vessel disruption** in open long bone fractures, leading to **inadequate oxygen delivery** and **impending cardiovascular collapse**. The management decision hinges on **immediate transfusion** with **universally compatible blood** lacking both **A/B antigens** and **Rh factor** to prevent **acute hemolytic reaction**. Type-specific or crossmatched blood excluded because **time delay for typing** (15-45 minutes) would cause **irreversible shock** and patient lacks **immunologic safety** with **antigen-positive products** before **antibody screening** completion. Because **life-threatening hemorrhage** requires immediate oxygen-carrying capacity restoration, delaying risks **cardiac arrest** through **critical tissue hypoxia**, therefore **O-negative packed RBCs** are required. Administered **before type and crossmatch completion** because **universal donor status** (lacking A, B, and D antigens) prevents **ABO incompatibility** and **Rh sensitization**, whereas waiting for **type-specific products** causes **irreversible end-organ damage** in patients with **hemoglobin <7 g/dL** and **ongoing hemorrhage**. **O-positive blood** is contraindicated because **Rh antigen exposure** risks **sensitization** in potentially **Rh-negative females of childbearing age**, causing **hemolytic disease of newborn** in future pregnancies through **anti-D antibody formation**.

question: A 26 year old male patient sustained stab injury to his neck of two hours duration. Upon presentation, he can communicate and there is no active bleeding through the wound. The wound exploration revealed that he was stabbed at the level of C-6 anteriorly with breech of platysma. Which of the following signs mandates surgical exploration?
explanation: Penetrating neck trauma at **C-6 level (Zone II)** with **platysma violation**, **stable communication**, **no active bleeding**, and **clinical examination findings** indicates **potential vascular or aerodigestive injury** requiring risk stratification, which results from **proximity to carotid artery, internal jugular vein, trachea, and esophagus** within the **anatomic boundaries** (cricoid to angle of mandible), leading to **selective management** based on **hard versus soft signs**. The management decision hinges on **presence of hard signs** indicating **active vascular compromise** requiring immediate intervention. Soft signs excluded because they represent **potential injury** warranting **further imaging** but would not mandate **immediate operative exploration** without **evidence of ongoing ischemia** or **airway compromise**. Because **pulselessness** indicates **arterial occlusion or transection**, delaying risks **irreversible cerebral ischemia** through **absent distal perfusion**, therefore **immediate surgical exploration** is required. Initiated **before complete neurologic deficit develops** because **carotid artery injury** with **absent pulse** demonstrates **complete flow interruption**, whereas waiting for **stroke symptoms** causes **tissue infarction** in the **4-6 hour window** for **revascularization**, violating **time-dependent salvage principles** in patients with **hard vascular signs**.

question: A 30 year old female patient involved in road traffic accident of 6 hours duration. She sustained trauma to her abdomen and complaining of hematuria. On examination she was in pain, vital signs are within normal range. On abdominal examination there was no tenderness. Investigations: normal CBC, CT scan of the abdomen shows non expanding peri-renal hematoma confined to the renal retroperitoneum. What is the grade of this renal injury?
explanation: Blunt abdominal trauma with **hematuria**, **stable vital signs**, **no abdominal tenderness**, **normal CBC**, and **CT showing non-expanding perirenal hematoma confined to Gerota's fascia** indicates **moderate renal parenchymal injury**, which results from **cortical laceration 1 cm)**, **collecting system rupture**, or **vascular pedicle injury** and would not demonstrate **contained hematoma** with **renal segment preservation** in **Grade IV-V injuries**. Because **Grade II renal trauma** represents **1 cm cortical depth** or **collecting system involvement** not demonstrated on imaging.

question: A 30 year old male factory worker sustained powder type of chemical burn. He came immediately to the hospital and on physical examination he has erythematous change over the right upper extremity with the powder still there. What should be the first treatment protocol?
explanation: Chemical exposure with **powder residue on skin**, **erythematous changes**, and **immediate presentation** indicates **dry chemical burn**, which results from **direct tissue contact with alkaline or acidic powder** causing **progressive protein denaturation** through **moisture-activated reactions**, leading to **deepening injury** until chemical removal is complete. The management decision hinges on **preventing water activation** of **hygroscopic substances** that **generate exothermic reactions** when wet. Immediate irrigation excluded because certain powders including **elemental sodium, lithium, or phenol derivatives** undergo **violent exothermic reactions** with water, causing **thermal injury** and would not permit **safe decontamination** before **mechanical removal** of dry material. Because **dry chemical powder** requires complete removal before water contact, delaying risks **accelerated tissue destruction** through **moisture-catalyzed reactions**, therefore **brushing off powder** is required. Performed **before irrigation** because **mechanical removal** of **water-reactive substances** prevents **exothermic heat generation** and **deeper tissue penetration**, whereas premature washing causes **activation of dormant chemicals**, violating **decontamination principles** in patients with **particulate exposures** requiring **dry removal first**.

question: A 30 year old male patient is presented after road traffic accident. The patient moans, doesn't open his eyes to painful stimuli, and has decerebrate posture. What is the GCS of the patient?
explanation: Road traffic accident with **no eye opening to pain (E1)**, **moaning sounds (V2)**, and **decerebrate posturing (M2)** indicates **severe traumatic brain injury**, which results from **diffuse axonal injury** or **brainstem compression** causing **impaired reticular activating system function**, leading to **depressed consciousness** with **extensor motor responses** from **red nucleus disinhibition** below the **midbrain level**. The management decision hinges on **accurate Glasgow Coma Scale calculation** summing **eye (1-4)**, **verbal (1-5)**, and **motor (1-6)** components to determine **injury severity** and **intubation need**. Alternative scores excluded because patient demonstrates **specific responses** (not absent): **moaning constitutes incomprehensible sounds (V2)**, not **no sounds (V1)**, and **decerebrate posture represents abnormal extension (M2)**, not **no movement (M1)** or **flexion (M3)**. Because **GCS components** require precise scoring, the **total is E1 + V2 + M2 = 5**, indicating **severe TBI** requiring **immediate airway protection**. Calculated as **eye opening: none to pain (1 point)**, **verbal: moaning/incomprehensible sounds (2 points)**, **motor: decerebrate/abnormal extension (2 points)**, totaling **5**, which mandates **endotracheal intubation** for **GCS ≤8**, therefore accurate scoring prevents **delayed airway intervention** in patients with **impending respiratory failure** from **brainstem dysfunction**.

question: A 30 year old male sustained injury as he was gored by an ox. He has developed paraplegia with sensory level at T4. His BP is 80/50 mmHg, PR of 60/min, RR of 20/min. The patient was previously healthy and is not on any medication. The patient was presented an hour after the injury. What is the cause of low BP in the patient?
explanation: Penetrating trauma with **paraplegia**, **T4 sensory level**, **hypotension (80/50 mmHg)**, **bradycardia (60 bpm)**, **previously healthy**, and **acute presentation** indicates **neurogenic shock**, which results from **spinal cord injury above T6** causing **loss of sympathetic outflow** from **descending autonomic pathways** in the **intermediolateral cell columns (T1-L2)**, leading to **unopposed parasympathetic tone** with **peripheral vasodilation** and **loss of cardiac sympathetic drive**. The management decision hinges on **bradycardia with hypotension**, pathognomonic for **neurogenic etiology** distinguishing from **hypovolemic shock**. Spinal shock excluded because this describes **transient areflexia below injury level**, not **hemodynamic instability**, and patient would not demonstrate **cardiovascular collapse** from **absent reflexes** without **autonomic dysfunction**. Because **cervical or high thoracic spinal cord injury** disrupts **sympathetic innervation**, delaying risks **tissue hypoperfusion** through **persistent vasodilation**, therefore **vasopressor therapy** is required. Initiated **before fluid resuscitation alone** because **neurogenic shock** responds poorly to **volume loading** without **alpha-agonist support**, as **vascular tone loss** prevents **effective preload utilization**, whereas **excessive crystalloid** causes **pulmonary edema** in patients with **normal cardiac function** but **absent sympathetic vasoconstriction**.

question: A forty year old male patient sustained road side accident of two hours duration. He complains of generalized abdominal pain. On physical examination, blood pressure-80/40 mmHg, pulse rate-120/min and feeble. Guarding and rigidity noted on abdominal examination and has bruising over the bilateral flank. Which one is the most likely cause of hypotension?
explanation: Blunt abdominal trauma with **generalized pain**, **hypotension (80/40 mmHg)**, **tachycardia (120 bpm)**, **guarding/rigidity**, and **bilateral flank ecchymosis (Grey Turner sign)** indicates **retroperitoneal hemorrhage**, which results from **blunt force to posterior abdomen** causing **lumbar vertebral fractures**, **renal pedicle avulsion**, or **iliac vessel disruption** in the **retroperitoneal space**, leading to **massive blood accumulation** (up to 4L capacity) within **non-expandable fascial boundaries**. The management decision hinges on **bilateral flank bruising**, pathognomonic for **retroperitoneal bleeding** distinguishing from **intraperitoneal sources**. Isolated solid organ injury excluded because **Grey Turner sign** requires **retroperitoneal blood dissection** into **flank soft tissues** and would not appear from **intraperitoneal splenic** or **hepatic bleeding** confined to **peritoneal cavity**. Because **retroperitoneal hemorrhage** lacks **peritoneal signs** proportionate to **blood loss volume**, delaying risks **exsanguination** through **occult massive bleeding**, therefore **immediate CT imaging** or **exploratory laparotomy** is required. Diagnosed **before isolated organ injury** because **bilateral flank ecchymosis** indicates **posterior compartment involvement**, requiring **different surgical approach** (retroperitoneal exploration vs. standard laparotomy), whereas **assuming intraperitoneal source** causes **missed injuries** in the **zone I-III retroperitoneum** needing **specialized vascular control**.

question: A 50 -year old male patient presented to the emergency department with a complaint of severe epigastric stabbing pain of 12 hours duration after a meal, the pain radiates to the back and get relieved on leaning forward.He has also associated nausea and vomiting. The patient is known alcoholic for the last 15 years. On examination he is sick looking and has stable vital signs. On investigations he has normal CBC, abdominal ultrasound and abdominal x – ray. What is the next best investigative modality that helps in reaching at a diagnosis?
explanation: Chronic alcoholism with **severe epigastric pain radiating to back**, **relief with leaning forward**, **post-prandial onset**, **nausea/vomiting**, **stable vital signs**, and **negative imaging (ultrasound, x-ray)** indicates **acute pancreatitis**, which results from **alcohol-induced acinar cell injury** or **premature trypsinogen activation** within the **pancreatic parenchyma**, leading to **autodigestion** and **retroperitoneal inflammation** that irritates **posterior peritoneum** relieved by **anterior truncal flexion**. The management decision hinges on **biochemical confirmation** through **pancreatic enzyme elevation** when imaging is non-diagnostic. Alternative diagnoses excluded because patient lacks **biliary colic pattern** (intermittent pain), **peritoneal signs** (perforated viscus), or **vascular catastrophe** indicators and would not demonstrate **postural pain relief** characteristic of **pancreatic inflammation**. Because **acute pancreatitis diagnosis** requires **elevated lipase or amylase ≥3 times upper limit**, delaying risks **progression to necrotizing pancreatitis** without **early risk stratification**, therefore **serum amylase measurement** is required. Obtained **before advanced imaging (CT)** because **biochemical confirmation** establishes diagnosis when **ultrasound non-contributory** (pancreas often obscured by **bowel gas**), whereas **CT pancreas protocol** is reserved for **complications** (necrosis, pseudocyst) after **enzymatic diagnosis**, making **serum markers** the **appropriate next step** in patients with **classic presentation** but **negative initial imaging**.

question: A 55 year old male patient came with loss of consciousness after he sustained motor vehicle accident. Upon examination, blood pressure 180/100 mmHg, pulse rate-60/min, oxygen saturation-95%. He had a GCS of 8 with dilated and fixed pupil on right side with left side neurologic deficit. The next option of management is?
explanation: Traumatic brain injury with **GCS 8**, **Cushing's triad (hypertension 180/100 mmHg, bradycardia 60 bpm)**, **right fixed dilated pupil**, and **left hemiparesis** indicates **uncal herniation from epidural or subdural hematoma**, which results from **temporal lobe mass effect** causing **uncus displacement** over the **tentorial edge**, leading to **ipsilateral oculomotor nerve (CN III) compression** with **pupillary dilation** and **contralateral corticospinal tract compression** at the **cerebral peduncle**. The management decision hinges on **airway protection threshold (GCS ≤8)** preceding **definitive treatment**, as **inadequate oxygenation** or **aspiration** during **ICP management** or **surgical evacuation** causes **secondary brain injury**. Direct surgical intervention excluded because proceeding without **secured airway** risks **hypoxemia** and **hypercarbia-induced ICP elevation** during transport and would not permit **safe anesthesia induction** without **controlled ventilation**. Because **GCS ≤8** indicates **absent airway reflexes**, delaying risks **aspiration** or **respiratory arrest**, therefore **endotracheal intubation** is required. Performed **before ICP treatment or surgical evacuation** because **airway compromise** causes **immediate life threat** through **hypoxia** and **hypercarbia**, both worsening **cerebral edema**, whereas **attempting surgery** or **osmotic therapy** in **unprotected airway** violates **ATLS airway-first principles**, causing **preventable secondary injury** in patients requiring **controlled ventilation** for **safe ICP management** and **operative intervention**.

question: A farmer is presented to the emergency after he ingested an unknown substance. He is agitated, has pinpoint pupils and his pant is soaked in urine and feces. The chest is full of transmitted sounds on auscultation. His PR is 60/min and oxygen saturation is 80% on room air. What is the most likely poisoning agent that he took?
explanation: Agricultural exposure with **agitation**, **miosis (pinpoint pupils)**, **urinary/fecal incontinence**, **bronchial secretions (transmitted sounds)**, **bradycardia (60 bpm)**, and **hypoxemia (80% saturation)** indicates **cholinergic toxidrome from organophosphate poisoning**, which results from **irreversible acetylcholinesterase inhibition** at **synaptic clefts**, leading to **excessive acetylcholine accumulation** producing **muscarinic effects** (DUMBELS: diarrhea, urination, miosis, bronchospasm, emesis, lacrimation, salivation) and **nicotinic effects** (fasciculations, weakness). The management decision hinges on **muscarinic receptor overstimulation** pattern with **bradycardia and secretions** pathognomonic for **cholinergic crisis**. Anticholinergic toxicity excluded because patient demonstrates **opposite constellation** (miosis not mydriasis, bradycardia not tachycardia, increased not decreased secretions) and would not exhibit **SLUDGE syndrome** with **parasympathetic hyperactivity**. Because **organophosphate poisoning** causes **respiratory failure** from **bronchorrhea and bronchospasm**, delaying risks **death from asphyxiation**, therefore **atropine administration** is required. Initiated **before pralidoxime** because **muscarinic blockade** immediately reverses **life-threatening bronchial secretions** and **bradycardia**, whereas **oxime therapy** (reactivating cholinesterase) works slower and becomes ineffective after **24-48 hours** of **enzyme aging**, making **atropine** the **urgent first-line** intervention in patients with **cholinergic respiratory failure** requiring **secretion control** before **oxygenation optimization**.

question: A man is presented to the emergency after a road traffic accident. The patient is unresponsive, looks obese and had lots of secretions. The intern who first saw the patient tried to suck out the secretions, inserted oral airway and did chin lift, head tilt and jaw trust maneuvers to open the airway. He called you to evaluate the patient. What should the intern have avoided?
explanation: Blunt trauma with **unresponsiveness**, **secretions**, and **multiple airway maneuvers performed** indicates **potential cervical spine injury**, which results from **high-energy mechanism** in **unconscious patient** at risk for **vertebral fracture** or **ligamentous disruption**, leading to **spinal cord injury** if **neck manipulation** causes **vertebral displacement** with **cord compression**. The management decision hinges on **cervical spine precautions in trauma**, requiring **inline stabilization** without **hyperextension**. Alternative maneuvers excluded because **jaw thrust**, **chin lift**, and **airway adjuncts** can be performed safely with **spinal precautions**, whereas **head tilt** causes **atlanto-occipital extension** and would not maintain **neutral spine alignment** required for **cervical protection** in unresponsive trauma patients. Because **head tilt maneuver** extends the **atlanto-occipital joint**, delaying recognition risks **spinal cord transection** through **vertebral malalignment**, therefore this technique is **contraindicated in trauma**. Avoided **in favor of jaw thrust alone** because **head tilt-chin lift** requires **neck extension** that displaces **fractured vertebrae**, whereas **jaw thrust** achieves **airway opening** through **mandibular anterior displacement** without **cervical motion**, making **extension-based maneuvers** dangerous in patients with **unknown cervical integrity** requiring **inline stabilization** during **airway management**.

question: An 18 year old male sustained flame burn injury with an estimated body surface area of 30%. The patient's weight is 50kg. Your senior has advised you to give him a ringer's lactate IV after calculating the fluid requirement for the first 24 hours using parkland's formula. How much fluid does the patient require for first 24 hours?
explanation: Flame burn with **30% TBSA**, **50 kg weight**, and **Parkland formula requirement** indicates **major thermal injury** requiring **aggressive crystalloid resuscitation**, which results from **massive capillary leak** in **burned tissue** causing **intravascular volume depletion** through **inflammatory-mediated increased permeability**, leading to **hypovolemic shock** without adequate **fluid replacement**. The management decision hinges on **accurate calculation** using **4 mL × weight (kg) × %TBSA** for **first 24 hours**. Alternative volumes excluded because **underdosing** causes **renal hypoperfusion** with **acute tubular necrosis**, whereas **overdosing** risks **compartment syndrome** through **excessive tissue edema**, and precise calculation yields **4 × 50 × 30 = 6000 mL = 6 liters**. Because **Parkland formula** prevents **burn shock** through **titrated crystalloid**, the calculation determines **6 liters lactated Ringer's** for **24 hours** (half in first 8 hours). Administered as **3 liters in first 8 hours** (from time of burn), then **remaining 3 liters over next 16 hours**, because **early aggressive resuscitation** prevents **irreversible renal injury** during the **acute capillary leak phase** (0-24 hours post-burn), whereas **delayed or inadequate volume** causes **acute kidney injury** from **prolonged hypoperfusion** in patients with **ongoing third-spacing** requiring **time-sensitive fluid restoration**.

question: An 86-year-old man presents to the emergency room within an hour onset of right hemiplegia and global aphasia. He has no significant medical history and his laboratory data are all normal. Neuroimaging finds no hemorrhage and no signs of acute ischemia. How do you proceed in managing this patient?
options: Avoid giving IV tissue plasminogen activator tPA as this is an old patient.
Refer the patient for mechanical thrombectomy.
Avoid giving IV tissue plasminogen activator tPA as brain MRI is normal.
explanation: Acute stroke with **right hemiplegia**, **global aphasia**, **presentation <1 hour**, **no hemorrhage on imaging**, and **absence of early ischemic changes** indicates **hyperacute middle cerebral artery (MCA) occlusion**, which results from **thromboembolic arterial blockage** in the **dominant hemisphere MCA territory** causing **Broca's and Wernicke's area involvement** plus **motor cortex ischemia**, leading to **language production/comprehension deficits** with **contralateral weakness**. The management decision hinges on **3-4.5 hour tPA window** when **no contraindications** exist. Age alone excluded as contraindication because **advanced age** does not prohibit **thrombolysis** in absence of **specific contraindications** (recent surgery, bleeding, uncontrolled hypertension), and **early imaging negativity** represents **expected finding** in **hyperacute stroke** (<6 hours) before **CT changes** develop. Because **presentation within 1 hour** falls within **thrombolysis window**, delaying risks **permanent disability** from **infarct expansion**, therefore **IV alteplase** is required. Administered **before considering thrombectomy** because **tPA eligibility** takes **priority** as **faster intervention** achieving **recanalization** in **small/medium vessel occlusions**, whereas **mechanical thrombectomy** requires **angiography suite preparation** causing **treatment delay**, making **IV thrombolysis** the **initial therapy** in patients meeting **time/imaging criteria** regardless of **age** when **no absolute contraindications** exist.

question: A 3 year-old child came to district hospital with whitish lesion at the center of the dark part of left eye which was noticed 5 months back. There was neither eye problem prior to this nor history of trauma. Visual acuity was 6/6 right eye and no light perception left eye. On torch examination there was whitish pupillary reflex on left eye. What best measure should betaken?
options: Counsel the family and send home as there is no visual potential
Refer the patient urgently to ophthalmologist
Tell the patients to seek better care at convenient time
Give an appointment for re-evaluation after two months
explanation: Pediatric patient with **leukocoria (white pupillary reflex)**, **progressive 5-month history**, **no light perception**, **normal contralateral eye**, and **no trauma** indicates **retinoblastoma**, which results from **RB1 gene mutation** causing **retinal cell malignancy** growing in the **posterior segment**, leading to **tumor filling vitreous cavity** producing **white reflex** (instead of normal **red reflex**) from **light reflecting off tumor surface**. The management decision hinges on **malignancy risk** in **leukocoria differential** requiring **urgent oncologic evaluation**. Benign causes excluded because **progressive painless vision loss** in **young child** with **complete blindness** suggests **malignant growth**, not **congenital cataract** (typically bilateral, present at birth) or **Coats disease** (older children, exudative changes), and patient would not demonstrate **no light perception** from **reversible pathology** without **extensive posterior involvement**. Because **retinoblastoma** represents **potentially fatal malignancy** requiring **early diagnosis**, delaying risks **metastatic spread** through **optic nerve invasion** or **intracranial extension**, therefore **immediate ophthalmology referral** is required. Arranged **before extended observation** because **95% survival** with **early treatment** (enucleation, chemotherapy) drops to **<50%** with **extraocular extension**, whereas **waiting months** permits **tumor growth** beyond **globe confinement**, violating **oncologic urgency principles** in patients with **pathognomonic leukocoria** requiring **fundoscopic examination** and **imaging** to prevent **life-threatening progression**.

question: A 67 year old female fell from a stair and hither head against the ground associated with this she complains projectile vomiting of 2 episodes. Up on presentation her GCS was 15/15 and mild abrasion over the forehead. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
explanation: Ground-level fall with **head strike**, **projectile vomiting (2 episodes)**, **GCS 15**, and **forehead abrasion** indicates **potential intracranial injury** requiring risk stratification, which results from **coup-contrecoup mechanism** causing **cortical contusion** or **subdural hematoma** in **elderly patient** with **brain atrophy** increasing **bridging vein vulnerability**, leading to **increased intracranial pressure** manifesting as **vomiting** despite **preserved consciousness**. The management decision hinges on **Canadian CT Head Rule** where **≥2 episodes vomiting** constitutes **high-risk criterion** for **clinically important brain injury**. Observation alone excluded because **vomiting after head trauma** indicates **potential mass lesion** requiring **imaging confirmation**, and elderly patient would not demonstrate **benign clinical course** with **recurrent emesis** without **structural pathology** assessment. Because **vomiting post-trauma** represents **high-risk feature**, delaying risks **missed expanding hematoma**, therefore **non-contrast head CT** is required. Obtained **before clinical deterioration** because **elderly patients** develop **chronic subdural hematomas** that **expand slowly** over **days-weeks**, whereas **waiting for neurologic decline** causes **irreversible herniation** in patients with **initially compensated lesions** requiring **early detection** for **timely evacuation**. **MRI** is contraindicated because **prolonged scan time** (30-60 minutes) delays **acute management** and lacks **superior sensitivity** for **acute hemorrhage** compared to **CT** in **emergency settings**.

question: A 35 years old male patient presented to the emergency room after sustaining a road traffic accident. By following the ATLS protocol, he was diagnosed with hemorrhagic shock. The bleeding was controlled and transfusion with across-matched blood started. Few minutes after the start the patient was noticed to develop fever associated with severe hypotension. What should be the next step in the management of this patient?
options: Stop transfusion and notify the blood bank
Open another IV line and resuscitate while continuing transfusion
Reassure the patient and give antipyretics
explanation: Hemorrhagic shock with **controlled bleeding**, **crossmatched blood transfusion**, and **acute onset fever with severe hypotension** occurring **minutes after transfusion start** indicates **acute hemolytic transfusion reaction**, which results from **ABO incompatibility** causing **recipient antibodies** binding **donor RBC antigens**, leading to **complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis** with **inflammatory cytokine release** (IL-1, TNF-alpha) producing **fever**, **hypotension**, and **DIC**. The management decision hinges on **immediate transfusion cessation** when **acute reaction** suspected, as continued **incompatible blood** infusion worsens **hemolysis**. Alternative diagnoses excluded because **timing (minutes)** indicates **immediate reaction** (not **delayed hemolytic** at 3-14 days or **febrile non-hemolytic** with **isolated fever** without **hypotension**), and patient would not demonstrate **cardiovascular collapse** from **minor allergic reaction** without **severe hemolysis**. Because **acute hemolytic reaction** causes **progressive intravascular destruction**, continuing transfusion risks **renal failure** from **hemoglobinuria**, therefore **stopping blood immediately** is required. Performed **before supportive measures** because **each milliliter of incompatible blood** increases **hemoglobin release** causing **acute tubular necrosis**, whereas **blood bank notification** enables **clerical error investigation** and **prevents additional incompatible units**, making **transfusion cessation** the **first action** in patients with **suspected ABO mismatch** requiring **hemolysis limitation** before **organ damage** becomes **irreversible**.

question: A 24 years old male sustained road traffic injury. He injured his left leg. He was taken to health center and was referred with posterior gutter. He arrived to your ER after two hours of the injury. At presentation he has excruciating pain over the injured leg. On examination left leg was swollen and distal capillary refill was sluggish. What is the next appropriate management?
explanation: Extremity trauma with **posterior splint application**, **excruciating pain**, **leg swelling**, and **sluggish capillary refill** indicates **impending compartment syndrome**, which results from **increased pressure within closed fascial compartments** from **hemorrhage** or **edema**, leading to **venous outflow obstruction** with **tissue ischemia** when **compartment pressure** exceeds **capillary perfusion pressure** (typically >30 mmHg or within 30 mmHg of diastolic BP). The management decision hinges on **external compression** from **circumferential splinting** exacerbating **compartment pressures**, requiring **immediate removal**. Alternative interventions excluded because **analgesics** mask **pain progression** (key monitoring parameter), **elevation** worsens **arterial inflow** when **capillary refill already compromised**, and **imaging** delays **pressure relief** when **clinical diagnosis** warrants **urgent fasciotomy consideration**. Because **tight splints** increase **external compartment pressure**, delaying risks **irreversible muscle necrosis** at **6 hours**, therefore **splint removal** is required. Performed **before other interventions** because **circumferential dressings** directly contribute to **elevated compartment pressure**, whereas removing **constricting devices** immediately reduces **external compression**, potentially **preventing fasciotomy** in **early cases** or **preserving time window** for **surgical decompression** in patients with **established syndrome** requiring **pressure optimization** before **ischemia becomes irreversible**.

question: A 45 year oldman is in your office for consultation of recent onset general malaise and fatigability. While walking into your office he suddenly collapsed. You realized that peripheral pulses are not palpable, apical impulse is absent, chest is not moving and you do not feel air coming through the mouth. What is the next best step?
options: Transport him to the emergency room
explanation: Sudden collapse with **absent peripheral pulses**, **absent apical impulse**, **no respiratory effort**, and **no air movement** indicates **cardiac arrest**, which results from **ventricular fibrillation**, **pulseless ventricular tachycardia**, **asystole**, or **pulseless electrical activity** causing **cessation of effective cardiac output**, leading to **absent circulation** and **cerebral hypoxia** with **irreversible brain injury** developing after **4-6 minutes**. The management decision hinges on **immediate CPR initiation** within the **critical first minutes** when **neurologic outcome** depends on **perfusion restoration**. Alternative actions excluded because **diagnostic testing** (glucose) or **medication searches** waste **critical seconds** during the **narrow resuscitation window**, and **transport delays** worsen **survival** when **immediate chest compressions** provide **only source** of **cerebral and coronary perfusion** before **defibrillation availability**. Because **cardiac arrest** causes **brain death** within **4-6 minutes**, delaying risks **irreversible anoxic injury**, therefore **immediate CPR** is required. Initiated **before any diagnostic steps** because **chest compressions** generate **critical perfusion pressure** (20-30% normal cardiac output) maintaining **minimal organ viability**, whereas **delays for glucose checks** or **transport** cause **progressive tissue hypoxia** beyond **reversibility threshold**, violating **CAB sequence principles** (circulation-airway-breathing) in patients with **witnessed arrest** requiring **immediate compressions** over **diagnostic investigations**.

question: An apparently healthy 15 year old female adolescent presented with loss of consciousness of 2 hours duration after she was found in her study room. Her friends found an unlabeled bottle with a spill of liquid on the floor. On objective evaluation she is lethargic with drooling of saliva and labored breathing and transmitted sound all over the lung fields. She experienced one episode of vomiting at emergency and it has garlicky odor. After securing the airway, breathing and circulation; What is the next appropriate management?
explanation: Adolescent with **altered consciousness**, **salivation**, **labored breathing**, **transmitted lung sounds (bronchorrhea)**, **vomiting with garlic odor**, and **unknown liquid ingestion** indicates **organophosphate poisoning**, which results from **irreversible acetylcholinesterase inhibition** causing **acetylcholine accumulation** at **muscarinic** (SLUDGE syndrome) and **nicotinic receptors**, leading to **cholinergic crisis** with **respiratory failure** from **bronchospasm** and **excessive secretions**. The management decision hinges on **muscarinic antagonism** after **airway secured**, as **atropine** reverses **life-threatening bronchorrhea** and **bradycardia**. Decontamination procedures excluded because **2-hour post-ingestion** timing makes **gastric emptying** ineffective (peak absorption at 30-120 minutes), and patient would not benefit from **gut clearance** after **systemic absorption** when **antidote therapy** addresses **established toxicity**. Because **organophosphate toxicity** causes **respiratory failure** from **bronchial secretions**, delaying risks **asphyxiation**, therefore **IV atropine** is required.
