question: A 23 year old male patient who is scheduled for emergency surgery under general anesthesia for acute appendicitis after being symptomatic for 36 hours. He has taken solid food an hour back. What is the appropriate alternative to minimize complication?
options: Rapid sequence induction of anesthetic agents
Bag ventilation before giving muscle relaxant
Keep him NPO for the next six hours
explanation: A 23-year-old with **acute appendicitis (36 hours)** requiring **emergency surgery** who **ate solid food 1 hour ago** indicates **full stomach** with **high aspiration risk**, which results from **delayed gastric emptying** in **acute illness** and **pain**, creating risk of **gastric content regurgitation** during **anesthesia induction** with **potential aspiration pneumonitis**. The management decision hinges on **preventing aspiration** while **not delaying necessary surgery**. The top differential, **delaying surgery 6 hours for NPO**, is excluded because **appendicitis at 36 hours** approaches **perforation risk (20-30% at 24-48 hours)**, and **delaying emergency surgery** for **routine NPO** increases **peritonitis** and **sepsis** risk outweighing **aspiration concerns**. **Rapid sequence induction (RSI) with cricoid pressure** is first-line, as **rapid administration of induction agent** (propofol/etomidate) followed **immediately by succinylcholine** and **endotracheal intubation without bag-mask ventilation** minimizes **time** with **unprotected airway**, while **cricoid pressure (Sellick maneuver)** occludes the **esophagus** preventing **passive regurgitation**. This is performed **before delaying surgery** because **RSI reduces aspiration risk to <1%** in **full-stomach patients**, and **modern anesthesia technique** allows **safe emergency surgery** without **dangerous surgical delays** that increase **appendiceal perforation** rates.

question: An apparently healthy young man to undergo fistulectomy. Fifteen minutes after spinal anesthesia, he developed hypotension. What is the best initial management for this patient?
options: Putting the patient in Trendelenburg position
explanation: A healthy young male **15 minutes post-spinal anesthesia** with **hypotension** indicates **neuraxial-induced sympathetic blockade**, which results from **local anesthetic spread** in the **subarachnoid space** blocking **sympathetic preganglionic fibers (T1-L2)**, causing **venous pooling**, **decreased venous return**, **reduced cardiac output**, and **vasodilation**. The management decision hinges on **rapid restoration of preload**. The top differential, **vasopressor-first approach**, is excluded because **spinal hypotension** primarily results from **venous pooling reducing preload** rather than **pure vasoconstriction deficit**, and **fluid loading** addresses the **primary mechanism** before **pharmacologic intervention**. **Intravenous crystalloid bolus (500-1000 mL)** is first-line, as **rapid volume expansion** increases **venous return** and **cardiac preload**, restoring **blood pressure** in **70-80% of spinal hypotension cases** through **augmented stroke volume**. This is administered **before vasopressors** because **fluid-responsive hypotension** resolves with **volume alone**, avoiding **unnecessary medications**, and **vasopressor use** without **adequate preload** causes **excessive afterload** with **decreased cardiac output** in **hypovolemic** patients.

question: A 50 year old male patient presented to the ER with failure to pass feces and flatus of two days duration. On examination, abdomen is grossly distended and tympanitic. Plain abdominal X-ray showed distended bowel loops with multiple peripheral air fluid level. Surgery was planned. When should prophylactic antibiotic be administered for this patient?
explanation: Two days of obstipation (no feces/flatus), **abdominal distension**, **tympany**, and **multiple peripheral air-fluid levels** on X-ray indicate **small bowel obstruction (SBO)**, which results from **mechanical blockage** causing **proximal bowel dilation** and **bacterial translocation risk** during surgical manipulation. The management decision hinges on **antibiotic timing relative to surgical incision** to achieve **therapeutic tissue concentrations** when bacteria are first encountered. The differential, **large bowel obstruction**, is excluded because peripheral (not central) air-fluid levels indicate small bowel, and colonic obstruction would show **haustra** on imaging. **Prophylactic antibiotics (cefoxitin or cefazolin + metronidazole)** are administered **60 minutes before incision**, allowing **peak serum and tissue concentrations** during bacterial exposure from bowel manipulation, reducing **surgical site infection (SSI)** incidence from 15-20% to 120 minutes causes **drug metabolism/clearance** before exposure, negating prophylactic benefit.

question: A 30 year old male patient was operated for perforated appendicitis. He has been taking IV antibiotics. On 5th postoperative day, he started to have wound site pussy discharge. WBC =13000 cells/mL and abdominal US was unremarkable. What will be the next step in the management of the patient?
options: Continue with the antibiotics for five more days
explanation: Postoperative day 5 **purulent wound discharge**, **leukocytosis (13,000 cells/mL)**, and **normal abdominal ultrasound** (excluding intra-abdominal abscess) indicate **superficial surgical site infection (SSI)**, which results from **bacterial colonization** of the subcutaneous space during contaminated surgery (**perforated appendicitis**), causing **local inflammation** without deep/organ-space involvement. The management decision hinges on **wound drainage** to remove infected material, as antibiotics cannot penetrate **purulent collections**. The differential, **deep/organ-space abscess**, is excluded because ultrasound shows **no fluid collections** and the patient lacks **systemic sepsis** (fever, tachycardia, hypotension) requiring percutaneous drainage. **Opening and washing the wound** is first-line, achieving **source control** by evacuating purulent material and allowing **secondary-intention healing** with wet-to-dry dressings, which reduces infection duration from 10-14 days to 5-7 days. This is initiated **before changing antibiotics** because **mechanical debridement** addresses the primary pathology (loculated pus), whereas antibiotic escalation treats **systemic spread** (not present here), and delays in drainage cause **fascial extension** or **necrotizing soft tissue infection**.

question: A 30 year old female patient come to the surgical OPD with the complaint of serosanguinous nipple discharge from her right breast. On examination, her vital signs were normal; has nipple discharge but no palpable mass. Ultrasound was non-revealing. Mammography with contrast injected to the duct revealed filling defect and ectasia in the nipples. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
explanation: **Serosanguinous unilateral nipple discharge**, **no palpable mass**, and **ductography showing filling defect with ductal ectasia** indicate **intraductal papilloma**, which results from **benign epithelial proliferation** within a **single lactiferous duct**, causing **friable tissue erosion** and **bloody discharge** when the papilloma abrades against duct walls. The management decision hinges on **ductography findings** (filling defect = intraluminal mass), as **diffuse duct ectasia alone** suggests fibrocystic changes, not focal lesions. The differential, **ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)**, is excluded because the patient is **30 years old** (DCIS peaks at 55-65 years), has **no microcalcifications** on mammography, and lacks **pathologic discharge** (clear/multiductal). **Surgical duct excision** is first-line, achieving **histologic diagnosis** (excluding malignancy in 5-10% of papillomas) and **definitive treatment** by removing the bleeding source. This is initiated **before observation** because **persistent serosanguinous discharge** in women <40 years requires **tissue diagnosis** to exclude **early-stage breast cancer**, and delays allow **undiagnosed DCIS progression** to invasive disease.

question: A 25-year-old woman undergoes an appendectomy for perforated appendicitis. On postoperative day 2, she develops erythema and pain at the surgical site, and a small amount of serosanguineous fluid drains from the wound. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F) and her pulse is 110/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
options: Continue current management and monitor wound healing
Explore the wound and debride any necrotic tissue
Perform a laparotomy and inspect the abdominal cavity
Start broad-spectrum antibiotics and change the dressing daily
Refer the patient to a plastic surgeon for wound closure
explanation: Postoperative day 2 **erythema**, **wound pain**, **serosanguineous drainage**, **fever (38.2°C)**, and **tachycardia (110/min)** indicate **early superficial surgical site infection (SSI)**, which results from **bacterial contamination** during surgery for **perforated appendicitis** (fecal spillage), causing **inflammatory mediator release** and **localized cellulitis**. The management decision hinges on **timing** (day 2 = typical SSI onset) and **lack of systemic sepsis** (no hypotension, mental status changes), making **wound exploration** appropriate. The differential, **necrotizing fasciitis**, is excluded because the patient lacks **crepitus**, **dusky skin**, **severe pain disproportionate to findings**, and **rapid progression** within 12-24 hours. **Exploring the wound and debriding necrotic tissue** is first-line, achieving **source control** by removing infected/devitalized tissue and allowing **aerobic healing**, which reduces infection progression from superficial to **deep/organ-space SSI**. This is initiated **before antibiotics alone** because **purulent collections** or **necrotic tissue** require **mechanical removal** (antibiotics cannot penetrate biofilms/avascular tissue), and delays cause **fascial involvement** or **intra-abdominal abscess formation**.

question: A 25-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of a painful lump in her right breast that she noticed 3 days ago. She is breastfeeding her 2-month-old infant. On physical examination, the lump is tender, warm, and erythematous. There is no nipple discharge or axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
explanation: **Tender, warm, erythematous breast lump** in a **breastfeeding woman** (2 months postpartum) without **fluctuance**, **nipple discharge**, or **lymphadenopathy** indicates **lactational mastitis**, which results from **bacterial entry** (usually **Staphylococcus aureus**) through **nipple fissures** into obstructed **lactiferous ducts**, causing **cellulitis** without abscess formation. The management decision hinges on **absence of fluctuance** (no abscess) and **early presentation** (3 days), making **antibiotic therapy** first-line. The differential, **inflammatory breast cancer**, is excluded because the patient is **breastfeeding** (physiologic inflammation), lacks **peau d'orange** or **nipple retraction**, and has **acute onset** (cancer progresses over weeks-months). **Starting antibiotics (dicloxacillin or cephalexin 500 mg QID for 10-14 days)** is first-line, achieving **bacterial eradication** by targeting **penicillinase-producing S. aureus**, which resolves symptoms in 48-72 hours. This is initiated **before incision and drainage** because **cellulitis without abscess** responds to antimicrobials alone, and premature drainage causes **milk fistula formation** or **duct injury**, while **continuing breastfeeding** prevents **duct obstruction** and **milk stasis**, which worsen infection.

question: A 20-year-old woman comes to the clinic for removal of stitches on her face. She had a laceration on her left cheek that was repaired with sutures 10 days ago. The wound is well-healed and there is no sign of infection. Which of the following is the most appropriate time interval for removal of facial stitches?
explanation: **Well-healed facial laceration** at **10 days post-repair** with **no infection** indicates appropriate timing for **suture removal**, as facial wounds require balancing **tensile strength** (preventing dehiscence) against **scarring** (minimizing stitch marks). The management decision hinges on **facial tissue vascularity** (rich blood supply allows faster healing) and **cosmetic outcome** (prolonged sutures cause **cross-hatching scars** from epithelial invasion along suture tracks). The differential timing, **14 days** (used for trunk/extremities), is excluded because **facial tissue** heals twice as fast due to **arterial density** and **thinner dermis**, achieving adequate strength by day 5-7. **Facial suture removal at 5-7 days** is first-line, achieving **70% wound tensile strength** (sufficient to prevent dehiscence) while minimizing **railroad track scarring** from prolonged foreign body presence. This is initiated **before 14 days** because sutures left >7 days cause **epithelialization** along suture channels, creating **permanent pigmented marks**, while removal at **3 days** risks **wound separation** as tensile strength is only 30-40% at that time.

question: A term newborn boy is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit for respiratory distress and abdominal distension. He was born to a 25-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, who had no prenatal care. The delivery was complicated by meconium-stained amniotic fluid and fetal bradycardia. The Apgar scores were 3 and 5 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The newborn received positive pressure ventilation and endotracheal suctioning at birth. On examination, he has tachypnea, intercostal retractions, and decreased breath sounds on the right side. His abdomen is distended and tympanic. A plain abdominal radiograph shows a dilated colon filled with meconium and air-fluid levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: **Meconium-stained fluid**, **fetal bradycardia**, **low Apgar scores (3/5)**, **respiratory distress** (tachypnea, retractions, decreased right-sided breath sounds), **abdominal distension**, and **dilated colon with meconium/air-fluid levels** on X-ray indicate **meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS)**, which results from **fetal hypoxia** triggering **gasping** that draws meconium into airways, causing **chemical pneumonitis**, **airway obstruction**, and **ventilation-perfusion mismatch**. The abdominal findings reflect **air swallowing** during resuscitation (positive pressure ventilation), not primary bowel pathology. The differential, **congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH)**, is excluded because the patient has **bilateral lung findings** (not unilateral scaphoid abdomen), and X-ray shows **bowel gas in abdomen** (not chest). **Supportive care (oxygen, mechanical ventilation if hypoxemic)** plus **pulmonary vasodilators (inhaled nitric oxide 20 ppm)** if persistent pulmonary hypertension develops is first-line, achieving **oxygenation** and **reversing hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction** that causes right-to-left shunting. This is initiated **before surfactant therapy** because MAS involves **surfactant inactivation** (not deficiency as in RDS), making exogenous surfactant minimally effective, and delays in vasodilator use cause **refractory hypoxemia** from persistent fetal circulation.

question: A 20-year-old man presents with a laceration on his forehead after a fall. He has no other injuries or medical problems. On physical examination, the laceration is 3 cm long and 1 cm deep, and it crosses the midline of the forehead. There is bleeding and swelling around the wound. The patient reports numbness on the upper part of his forehead. What is the most likely nerve injured by the laceration?
explanation: **Midline forehead laceration** (3 cm, crossing midline) with **numbness over upper forehead** indicates **supraorbital nerve injury**, which results from **laceration transecting** the nerve as it exits the **supraorbital foramen/notch** (1-2 cm above orbital rim, medial to mid-pupillary line), causing **sensory loss** over the **ipsilateral forehead, anterior scalp, and upper eyelid**. The management decision hinges on **anatomic correlation**: midline wounds crossing the **frontal bone** intersect the **medial branch** of the supraorbital nerve. The differential, **supratrochlear nerve injury**, is excluded because supratrochlear innervates the **medial lower forehead and medial upper eyelid** (not upper forehead/scalp), and exits **medial to supraorbital foramen** (spared by midline laceration). **Wound exploration and primary repair** with **microsurgical nerve coaptation** if nerve ends are visible is first-line, achieving **sensory recovery** in 60-70% of cases within 6-12 months via **axonal regeneration**. This is initiated **before wound closure** because **delayed repair** (>72 hours) causes **nerve retraction** and **scar formation**, reducing successful coaptation rates from 70% to 30-40%, while **unrepaired transection** results in **permanent anesthesia** over the forehead.

question: A 28-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She has a history of pelvic inflammatory disease and tubal ligation. A urine pregnancy test is positive. A transvaginal ultrasound shows a 3 x 3 cm mass in the left fallopian tube. Her serum beta-hCG level is 3000 mIU/mL. What is the best management option for this patient?
explanation: **Positive pregnancy test**, **left adnexal mass (3 × 3 cm)** on ultrasound, **beta-hCG 3000 mIU/mL**, **prior tubal ligation**, and **pelvic inflammatory disease** (PID) history indicate **ectopic pregnancy**, which results from **tubal scarring** (from PID) or **surgical disruption** (tubal ligation failure, 1 in 200) obstructing **embryo migration** to the uterus, causing **tubal implantation** and **rupture risk**. The management decision hinges on **mass size (3 cm)** and **beta-hCG >1500 mIU/mL**, making **surgical intervention** first-line over medical therapy. The differential, **heterotopic pregnancy** (intrauterine + ectopic), is excluded because ultrasound shows **no intrauterine gestational sac**, and heterotopic occurs in 3.5 cm within 48-72 hours. This is initiated **before methotrexate** because **mass size >3.5 cm**, **beta-hCG >5000 mIU/mL**, **fetal cardiac activity**, or **hemodynamic instability** are contraindications to medical management, and delays in surgery cause **tubal rupture** with **hemoperitoneum** requiring emergency laparotomy and transfusion.

question: A 45-year-old woman undergoes a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic gallstones. During the procedure, the surgeon accidentally injures the common bile duct. The injury is recognized intraoperatively and repaired with a T-tube. The patient is discharged home on postoperative day 3 with the T-tube in place. She is instructed to return in 6 weeks for a cholangiogram and T-tube removal. Two weeks later, she develops fever, chills, and right upper quadrant pain. She also notices that the drainage from the T-tube has increased and become purulent. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: **Postoperative day 14 fever/chills**, **RUQ pain**, **increased purulent T-tube drainage**, and **history of intraoperative bile duct injury** indicate **cholangitis**, which results from **bacterial colonization** of obstructed or **stagnant bile** (from **T-tube malposition**, **stricture formation**, or **retained stones**), causing **ascending infection** with **gram-negative organisms** (E. coli, Klebsiella) producing **Charcot triad** (fever, RUQ pain, jaundice). The management decision hinges on **purulent drainage** (indicating **infected bile**) and **systemic signs** (fever/chills = bacteremia), requiring urgent intervention. The differential, **bile leak**, is excluded because **increased purulent T-tube output** (not peritoneal drainage) indicates **biliary obstruction with infection**, and leaks present with **decreased** T-tube output plus **peritoneal signs**. **Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics (piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375 g Q6H or ciprofloxacin + metronidazole)** plus **T-tube cholangiography** to identify obstruction is first-line, achieving **bacterial eradication** and **drainage optimization** by detecting **stricture**, **tube malposition**, or **retained debris**. This is initiated **before ERCP** because **T-tube in situ** allows **diagnostic cholangiography** without sphincterotomy risk, and delays cause **septic shock** from **biliary bacteremia** spreading to **portal circulation**.

question: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) presents to the clinic with progressive dysphagia, weight loss, and hoarseness. He has a 40-pack-year history of smoking and drinks alcohol occasionally. On examination, he has a palpable left supraclavicular lymph node. A barium swallow shows a stricture in the distal esophagus. An upper endoscopy with biopsy confirms the diagnosis of esophageal cancer. What is the most likely histologic type of this patient's cancer?
explanation: **Progressive dysphagia**, **weight loss**, **hoarseness** (recurrent laryngeal nerve invasion), **distal esophageal stricture**, **GERD history**, **palpable left supraclavicular lymph node** (Virchow node = metastasis), **40-pack-year smoking**, and **alcohol use** indicate **esophageal adenocarcinoma**, which results from **chronic GERD** causing **Barrett esophagus** (intestinal metaplasia of distal esophagus), progressing through **dysplasia** to **invasive cancer** over 10-20 years. The management decision hinges on **distal location** (adenocarcinoma predominates in lower third, 60-70% of cases) and **GERD history** (strongest risk factor for adenocarcinoma, relative risk 7.7). The differential, **squamous cell carcinoma**, is excluded because squamous lesions arise in **proximal/mid-esophagus** (not distal), are linked to **smoking/alcohol** (not GERD), and have **declined in incidence** (now 30% of esophageal cancers vs. 60% adenocarcinoma). **Staging with CT chest/abdomen, PET scan, and endoscopic ultrasound** followed by **neoadjuvant chemoradiation (carboplatin/paclitaxel + 50.4 Gy)** for locally advanced disease (T3-4 or N+) is first-line, achieving **tumor downstaging** and **improved R0 resection rates** (75% vs. 55% with surgery alone). This is initiated **before esophagectomy** because **neoadjuvant therapy** improves 5-year survival from 25% to 40% in stage II-III disease, and delays in staging allow **metastatic progression** to liver/lung (30% within 6 months).
